comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: That's a great photo. Seems like there has been a bit of retouching to the swag, billy and trouser legs to make them more defined, but I'd be interested in an expert opinion. Good to compare with "On the wallaby track" from the Tyrrell Collection here: www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/2363534490/ ADDED: Oh, I see now through at the persistent URL, that these were glass slides for display at an exhibition, so it is understandable that some features were retouched to give more definition on the big screen. Maybe some of the trees in the background have been blurred in processing too.

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: BobMeade - the whole photo has been touched up extensively, but the eyes most strikingly of all. In the original only the whites of his eyes are visible and it gives the image a powerful aspect. The State Library have the original, but only digitised in low definition. A sharper version can be seen reproduced on p. 78 of Gaslight Sydney by Louise Johnson (Sydney: George Allen & Unwin, 1984). The State Library further define the location as Walbundry Station.

47201412@N02
comment._content: Sing along! There's an MP3 from New Theatre's 1955 production 'Reedy River' here - www.reasoninrevolt.net.au/bib/PR0000671.htm MY OLD BLACK BILLY (lyrics – Edward Harrington) I've humped me bluey through all the states With my old black billy the best of mates For years I've camped and toiled and tramped Over roads that are rough and hilly I've carried me sensible, indispensable Old Black Billy Chorus: My old black billy, my old black billy whether the wind be warm or chilly I always find when the shadows fall That me old black billy's the best mate of all When me tramping days at last are o'er And I drop my swag at that Golden Door Saint Peter will stare when he sees me there And he'll say, "Poor wandering Willie Come in with your sensible, indispensable Old Black Billy."
